background: A chemical plant is considering purchasing two types of generators, A and B, which produce hydrogen using different processes along with producing pollutants. The plant has a minimum hydrogen production requirement as well as a cap on the maximum pollutants allowed.
constraints: Number of generator A is non-negative
Number of generator B is non-negative
Total hydrogen production must be at least MinHydrogen
Total pollutants produced must be at most MaxPollutants
objective: Minimize the total number of generators A and B needed
description: A chemical plant can buy two types of generators, generator A and generator B, which use two different processes to generate hydrogen. Generator A uses an electrolysis process and produces \param{HydrogenA} cubic meters of hydrogen as well as \param{PollutantsA} units of pollutants every day. Generator B uses a fermentation process to produce \param{HydrogenB} cubic meters of hydrogen per day while outputting \param{PollutantsB} units of pollutants. The chemical plant must make a minimum of \param{MinHydrogen} cubic meters of hydrogen per day but due to environmental restrictions they can produce at most \param{MaxPollutants} units of pollutant. How many of each type of generator should they buy to minimize the number of generators needed?
